titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brooklyn periodical illustrations BCMS.0003
titlestmt.author: Ben Gocker, Librarian; Ally Malinenko, Librarian; Diana Bowers-Smith, Archivist

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-08 15:24:43 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Brooklyn periodical illustrations
did.abstract: This collection covers more than a century of Brooklyn history, with periodical illustrations depicting historic people, structures and events in Brooklyn predominantly from the era before the rise of photography.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This is a composite collection from many different sources, predominantly purchases.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged into series by subject. Within each series, the items are listed alphabetically by title.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn periodical illustrations, BCMS.0003, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Formerly known as the Brooklyn Prints Collection. Renamed in 2022 as part of planning to integrate BHS materials into the collection and to alleviate confusion about the collection's contents.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: King, Moses. King's Views of Brooklyn. New York: M. King, 1904. 917.472 K53

Stiles, Henry. The civil, political, professional and ecclesiastical history and commercial and industrial record of the County of Kings and the City of Brooklyn, N.Y. from 1683 to 1884. New York: Munsell, 1884. F127.K5 S8 1884
Harper's Weekly, Scientific American, and Ballou's Pictorial Drawing-Room Companion are available digitally on Hathi Trust.
Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper and American Architect and Building News are available digitally on the Internet Archive and Hathi Trust.
Gleason's Pictorial Drawing Room Companion is available digitally on the Internet Archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of the illustrations in this collection come from popular magazines and journals of the 19th century, including Harper's Weekly, Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, and Scientific American. Many are also taken from Henry R. Stiles's History of Kings County (see "Related Materials" for bibliographic information). The bulk dates of the collection are 1884–1904; images dated after 1930 are generally reprints of 19th century prints.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
